filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of forty-three pencil drawings produced by Blake during his first decade as an independent artist, 1779-1790. Drawing lies at the core of Blake's life as an artist. Pencil was his preferred medium for sketching—more flexible, less expensive, and more easily corrected than pen and ink or chalk. Preliminary work with the pencil preceded more finished work, either as separate sketches for prints and paintings or as drawings underlying water colors. Blake's nineteenth-century writings on the arts testify to his conviction that drawing was fundamental to all pictorial expression: "The distinction that is made in modern times between a Painting and a Drawing proceeds from ignorance of art. The merit of a Picture is the same as the merit of a Drawing" (*A Descriptive Catalogue*, Erdman page 549); "Let a Man who has made a Drawing go on & on & he will produce a Picture or Painting but if he chooses to leave off before he has spoild it he will Do a Better Thing[.]" (*Public Address*, Erdman page 576); "Painting is Drawing on Canvas & Engraving is Drawing on Copper & Nothing Else…& he who Draws best must be the best Artist…." (*Public Address*, Erdman page 582); "Dear Sir, excuse my enthusiasm or rather madness, for I am really drunk with intellectual vision whenever I take a pencil or graver into my hand…." (letter to William Hayley, 1804, Erdman page 757).
Blake no doubt executed a great many more pencil drawings than those extant today. Sketches were not intended for exhibition or sale; most were probably discarded, while others may have been retained only because of more developed compositions on the other side of the leaves. Even the slightest and least aesthetically ambitious drawings offer insights into the origins and earliest realizations of Blake’s designs. These first thoughts on paper often tell us more about Blake’s habits of mind, when joined by eye and hand, than more finished works. Sketches are “the first fruits of [Blake’s] imagination,” as Geoffrey Keynes states in the introduction to his *Pencil Drawings of William Blake* (1927).
The forty-three pencil drawings presented here, produced in Blake’s first decade as an independent artist, show his early debt to academic standards of precise copying and to the neoclassical emphasis on outline. The first four works may have been drawn while Blake was a student in the Royal Academy schools. Other sketches are preliminaries for some of Blake’s most important designs. Among these are the *Study for “Glad Day”, or “Albion Rose”* (Object 6), Blake’s iconic vision of the human form divine in energetic pose, and three sketches (Objects 34-36) for illustrations to *Tiriel*, the only group of finished drawings Blake composed for one of his own poems. Several sketches are early efforts at picturing events in the Bible, Blake’s main inspiration for designs throughout his life. This biblical cluster includes *The Resurrection of the Dead* (Object 10), *Samuel Presenting Saul to the People* (Object 15), and *Job’s Wife and Other Sketches* (Object 31). Other studies, such as *Ugolino in Prison* and its verso (Objects 21-22), reveal the beginnings of subjects also of lifelong interest for Blake. Only a few drawings for Blake’s illuminated books have survived, but studies such as *Sketches for “The Book of Thel”* and *A Standing and a Recumbent Figure* (Objects 37-39) offer fascinating glimpses into Blake’s methods of graphic production and revision.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.name: Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens
provenance.note: Probably inherited from Blake by his wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, in lot 200 with 14 other works or lot 201 with 17 other works (2s. and 3s. respectively, both to the dealer Francis Harvey); offered by Harvey in a catalogue of c. 1865, titled "Plague," with 15 other "sketches in ink and pencil" (£3.3s.); Frederick Locker-Lampson by 1886; E. Dwight Church, who acquired numerous works from Locker-Lampson through Dodd, Mead, & Co. c. 1905; sold from the Church estate, Anderson Galleries, New York, 29 March 1916, lot 983, laid into a copy of Blake's *Illustrations of Dante* and described as "The Plague, done by Blake in pencil" ($110); removed from the Dante portfolio and acquired by the Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, apparently as part of a large group of miscellaneous drawings (the others not by Blake), at an unrecorded time prior to 1982.

objnote.p: The drawing is inscribed lower left in ink, "cker."(?), not by Blake. The inscription was probably added by a dealer or collector. This pencil sketch is a preliminary drawing for *Pestilence*, a water color of c. 1784 in the Bateson Collection (Butlin 190) which in turn is a preliminary for the water color of *Pestilence* in the City Art Gallery, Bristol, England (Butlin 192). Butlin dates the water colors to c. 1790-95 and c. 1795-1800. For the earlier dates of these works given here, see Joseph Viscomi, "*A Breach in a City the Morning After the Battle*: Lost or Found?," *Blake: An Illustrated Quarterly*, 28.2 (fall 1994): 44-61.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene illustrates at least seven figures-six adults and one child-who appear to be grieving, sick, or dead, perhaps from the plague. The rightmost figure, who is male, stands or walks facing left but bends his torso forward in a contracted position with head down. He has short curly hair and wears a knee-length skirt. His eyes may be closed. Both arms are bent at 90 degrees and raised slightly. He appears to point to the ground in front of him with his extended left index finger and holds a cane or crutch in his right hand. Both knees are bent. An indistinguishable object rests on the ground in between this figure and the second figure from the right, a male who faces and walks right with right leg bent and extended backward. This figure bends his head forward and wears a similar knee-length skirt. His visible right arm is at his side and he carries the front end of a stretcher or litter on which a draped dead(?) body rests facing up with head at right. The majority of this body is obscured by the three figures in the front left corner of the design. A standing gowned female figure with long hair faces forward and bends to the left to look at and hold the body of a second female figure who faces right and up but leans or falls to the left. This second female figure's head is back, her eyes are closed, and her breasts are exposed. She wears a skirt or gown over the lower part of her body. Her knees are bent and her right arm is at her side and may support the infant or child who lies facing up in her lap. This child's head is back and its eyes are closed. Its left arm dangles downward over the female figure's right leg. Both the adult female and the child may be dead or dying. Above this trio, two figures stand facing right near the left margin of the design. The female figure bends forward and raises both bent arms to clutch her head with her left hand and pull her long hair with her right hand. She wears a long-sleeved garment and looks toward the male figure walking to her right. The male figure behind her at left has short curly hair and his head is down. His eyes may be closed or, alternatively, he may look down toward the three figures in the lower left corner. His torso is bare and his right arm is at his side. Faint background lines suggest an architectural structure divided into three sections. It may include a large rectangular door or opening at left, a central arch or arched opening, and a diagonal opening, perhaps a hall or door, at right.

He has short curly hair and wears a knee-length skirt. His eyes may be closed. Both arms are bent at 90 degrees and raised slightly. He appears to point to the ground in front of him with his extended left index finger and holds a cane or crutch in his right hand. Both knees are bent. He may be old or sick, perhaps from the plague. An indeterminate object rests on the ground in between this figure and the second figure from the right.

The second figure from the right, who is male, faces and walks right with right leg bent and extended backward. This figure bends his head forward and down and wears a similar knee-length skirt. He may look down toward the contracted male figure in front of him at right. His visible right arm is at his side and he carries the front end of a stretcher or litter on which a draped dead(?) body rests facing up.

In addition to the seven visible figures in this design, another figure may lie prone on a stretcher or litter carried by the second figure from the right. This figure's body is draped, perhaps with a sheet, and its head is at right. The figure is likely dead. The majority of the body is obscured by the three figures in the front left corner of the design.

In the lower left corner of the design, a standing gowned female figure with long hair faces forward and bends to the left to look at and hold the body of a second female figure who leans or falls to the left. The standing figure's left arm is extended downward with fingers spread against the body of the second woman. Her right leg is bent and extended forward and may support the weight of the other female figure. Her left leg is extended backward with toes pointed down.

In the lower left corner, a standing female figure holds the body of a second female figure who faces right and up but leans or falls to the left. This second female figure's head is back, her eyes are closed, and her breasts are exposed. She wears a skirt or gown over the lower part of her body. Her knees are bent sharply and her bent right arm is at her side and may support the infant or child who lies facing up in her lap. Both the adult female and the child may be dead or dying, perhaps from the plague.

An infant or child with short hair lies with body prone facing up in the lap of the leftmost female figure in the lower left corner of the design. This child's head is back and its eyes are closed. Its left arm dangles downward over the female figure's right leg. Both the adult female and the child may be dead or dying, perhaps from the plague.

Two figures stand facing right near the left margin of the design. The female figure bends forward to the right and raises both bent arms to clutch her head with her left hand and pull her long hair with her right hand. She wears a long-sleeved garment and looks toward the male figure walking to her right. Her position and expression suggests despair or grief.

Two figures stand facing right near the left margin of the design. The male figure at left has short curly hair and his head is down. His eyes may be closed or, alternatively, he may look down toward the three figures in the lower left corner. His torso is bare and his right arm is at his side. Although his hands are not visible, he may carry the rear end of the stretcher or litter visible in the middle of the design.

Faint background lines suggest an architectural structure divided into three sections. It may include a large rectangular door or opening at left, a central arch or arched opening, and a diagonal opening, perhaps a hall or door, at right.
